<ce:figure id="FIG2">

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) Asymmetric unit structure of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BDC)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>. (b) Arrangement of Sm(III) atoms in the layer of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BDC)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (C, H, O atoms are omitted for clarity). (c) Coordination polyhedra for the two crystallographically independent Sm ions and a perspective view of the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (d) Packing diagram of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BDC)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

<ce:link locator="gr2b"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) Asymmetric unit structure of [Sm2(BDC)3(H2O)2] n . (b) Arrangement of Sm(III) atoms in the layer of [Sm2(BDC)3(H2O)2] n  (C, H, O atoms are omitted for clarity). (c) Coordination polyhedra for the two crystallographically independent Sm ions and a perspective view of the crystal structure of 1. (d) Packing diagram of [Sm2(BDC)3(H2O)2] n .

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

This article presents two lanthanide coordination polymers, [Ln2(BDC)3(H2O)2] n  (Ln=Sm, 1; Ln=Eu, 2; BDC=1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) prepared by the hydrothermal technique, in the presence of 3,5-lutidine. The two complexes are characterized by IR spectra and X-ray diffraction. The luminescent spectroscopy of complex 2 has also been investigated. Crystal data: 1, C24H16O14Sm2, Monoclinic, P21/n, a=13.362(4)Å, b=14.475(3)Å, c=13.568(2)Å, β=104.058(9)°, V=2545.7(10)Å3, Z=4, μ=4.642mm-1, D calc=2.163g/cm3, R 1=0.0237, wR 2=0.0587; 2, C24H16O14Eu2, Monoclinic, P21/n, a=13.316(4)Å, b=14.437(3)Å, c=13.540(2)Å, β=103.956(9)°, V=2526.1(10)Å3, Z=4, μ=4.994mm-1, D calc=2.188g/cm3, R 1=0.0373, wR 2=0.1184. In these structures, Ln ions connecting with BDC anions are distributed in a helix-like 2D network, which is interlinked together by carboxylic groups.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In recent years, metal coordination polymers have received increasing interest for their fascinating structures and potential applications in a lot of fields, such as catalysis, molecular recognition and so on . Compared with the synthesis of coordination polymers containing transition metals reported largely , few of lanthanide–metal coordination polymers have been investigated . In constructing coordination polymers, aromatic polycarboxylic acids such as 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid , 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid  and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid  are used extensively in the synthesis of coordination polymers. We selected 1,3-Benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) as a bifunctional ligand based on the consideration of its multiple coordination sites that may generate structures of higher dimensions. Its two carboxylic groups may be completely or only partly deprotonated and thus result in versatile coordination modes. Some typical coordination modes for 1,3-BDC anions are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="SC1"></ce:float-anchor> (a–f). A variety of coordination polymers containing the isophthalate ligand are focused mainly on those of transition or post-transition metals . To the best of our knowledge, few of lanthanide isophthalate coordination polymers have been reported .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, metal coordination polymers have received increasing interest for their fascinating structures and potential applications in a lot of fields, such as catalysis, molecular recognition and so on . Compared with the synthesis of coordination polymers containing transition metals reported largely , few of lanthanide-metal coordination polymers have been investigated . In constructing coordination polymers, aromatic polycarboxylic acids such as 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid , 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid  and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid  are used extensively in the synthesis of coordination polymers. We selected 1,3-Benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) as a bifunctional ligand based on the consideration of its multiple coordination sites that may generate structures of higher dimensions. Its two carboxylic groups may be completely or only partly deprotonated and thus result in versatile coordination modes. Some typical coordination modes for 1,3-BDC anions are summarized in   (a-f). A variety of coordination polymers containing the isophthalate ligand are focused mainly on those of transition or post-transition metals . To the best of our knowledge, few of lanthanide isophthalate coordination polymers have been reported .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Hydrothermal synthesis, which is usually used to prepare oxide base materials, has been adopted in the preparation of coordination polymers . It turns out that hydrothermal synthesis is an effective and promising method in synthesizing compounds difficult to synthesize by conventional means. Recently, the hydrothermal technique has been applied to the synthesis of lanthanide carboxylate complexes and succeeded in constructing enchanting structures .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Hydrothermal synthesis, which is usually used to prepare oxide base materials, has been adopted in the preparation of coordination polymers . It turns out that hydrothermal synthesis is an effective and promising method in synthesizing compounds difficult to synthesize by conventional means. Recently, the hydrothermal technique has been applied to the synthesis of lanthanide carboxylate complexes and succeeded in constructing enchanting structures .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">We selected H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC as a linker and adopted the hydrothermal technique, hoping to construct some novel lanthanide complexes with characteristic structures. Here we report syntheses and structural characteristics of two lanthanide coordination polymers with 1,3-BDC acid.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We selected H2BDC as a linker and adopted the hydrothermal technique, hoping to construct some novel lanthanide complexes with characteristic structures. Here we report syntheses and structural characteristics of two lanthanide coordination polymers with 1,3-BDC acid.

Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were obtained using a Philips X′ Pert PRO SUPER diffractometer with Cu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=1.5418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and apparatus

All Chemicals were of reagent grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. IR spectra were taken on a Bruker EQUINOX 55 FT-IR spectrometer photometer as KBr pellets in the 4000-400 cm-1 ranges. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were obtained using a Philips X' Pert PRO SUPER diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ=1.5418Å). Luminescence spectra of complex 2 were recorded on a Sahimadzu RF-5301PC spectrometer at room temperature. The excitation light source was a deuterium lamp and the excitation wavelength was 285 nm.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Preparation of complexes</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.5 mmol; Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, 174 mg; Eu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, 176 mg), 36% HCl 0.3 ml (0.36 mmol), 1.5 mmol of 1,3-BDC acid (250 mg), 0.5 ml 3,5-lutidine and 10 ml H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was put into a 23 ml Teflon coated stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 4 days. After cooled to room temperature naturally, a large amount of needle-liked crystals were obtained. The crystals were separated by vacuum filtration and washed with distill water and absolute alcohol.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of complexes

A mixture of Ln2O3 (0.5 mmol; Sm2O3, 174 mg; Eu2O3, 176 mg), 36% HCl 0.3 ml (0.36 mmol), 1.5 mmol of 1,3-BDC acid (250 mg), 0.5 ml 3,5-lutidine and 10 ml H2O was put into a 23 ml Teflon coated stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 4 days. After cooled to room temperature naturally, a large amount of needle-liked crystals were obtained. The crystals were separated by vacuum filtration and washed with distill water and absolute alcohol.

elements.clean_text:
X-Ray crystallography

Crystal structure of 1 and 2 were determined by single crystal XRD. Suitable single crystals were selected and mounted on a Mar345 diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatized MoKα radiation (λ=0.71073Å), operating in the ω-2θ scanning mode. The raw data was processed using automar (release version 1.3.0) program to yield the reflection files. Subsequent calculations were carried out using the shelx 97 program. Structures were solved by direct methods using the program shelxs 97  and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using shelxl 97 . Hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically to the organic molecules. Crystal parameters and details of data collection and structure refinement are summarized in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Infrared spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The IR spectrums of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit broad peaks at 3438 and 3453 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively, which assigned to water molecules. The IR spectrum of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups in the usual region at 1613 and 1546 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for asymmetric stretching and at 1453 and 1389 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for symmetric stretching. For complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the characteristic bands of the dicarboxylate unit occur at 1614 and 1548 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for asymmetric stretching and at 1454 and 1390 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for symmetric stretching. Those at 3080, 1479, 826, 745, 713, 701, 655 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 3083, 1480, 827, 746, 713, 701, 655 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are due to phenyl group. IR spectra support the results of the X-ray analysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Infrared spectroscopy

The IR spectrums of complex 1 and 2 exhibit broad peaks at 3438 and 3453 cm-1, respectively, which assigned to water molecules. The IR spectrum of complex 1 shows characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups in the usual region at 1613 and 1546 cm-1 for asymmetric stretching and at 1453 and 1389 cm-1 for symmetric stretching. For complex 2, the characteristic bands of the dicarboxylate unit occur at 1614 and 1548 cm-1 for asymmetric stretching and at 1454 and 1390 cm-1 for symmetric stretching. Those at 3080, 1479, 826, 745, 713, 701, 655 cm-1 for 1 and 3083, 1480, 827, 746, 713, 701, 655 cm-1 for 2 are due to phenyl group. IR spectra support the results of the X-ray analysis.

The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor> and selected bond distances are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL2"></ce:float-anchor>. There are two crystallographically independent samarium ions in the asymmetric unit. The coordination environment of Sm1 is pentagonal bipyramidal. The pentagonal plane is composed of four carboxylate oxygen atoms and a water oxygen atom, and the two apical sites are taken by another two carboxylate oxygen atoms. The coordination polyhedron around Sm2 is a capped trigonal prism that contains six carboxylate oxygen atoms and one water oxygen atom (). The Sm–O distances range from 2.298(3) to 2.546(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, giving the average bond distance of 2.392(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The distance of Sm1⋯Sm2 is 4.739<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structures of [Ln2(BDC)3(H2O)2] n  (Ln=Sm, 1; Ln=Eu, 2)

Single crystal XRD studies revealed that the structure of complex 1 is a 2D coordination polymer made up of layers. The asymmetric unit of 1 is depicted in   and selected bond distances are listed in  . There are two crystallographically independent samarium ions in the asymmetric unit. The coordination environment of Sm1 is pentagonal bipyramidal. The pentagonal plane is composed of four carboxylate oxygen atoms and a water oxygen atom, and the two apical sites are taken by another two carboxylate oxygen atoms. The coordination polyhedron around Sm2 is a capped trigonal prism that contains six carboxylate oxygen atoms and one water oxygen atom (). The Sm-O distances range from 2.298(3) to 2.546(3)Å, giving the average bond distance of 2.392(2)Å. The distance of Sm1⋯Sm2 is 4.739Å.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the structure of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, all H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC molecules are completely deprotonated and all oxygen atoms from the carboxylic groups of BDC anions take part in coordination with metal ions. The BDC anions adopt only one type of coordination mode: two bridging bidentates () to coordinate with Sm ions. In the asymmetric unit, there are three BDC anions (), each of which, respectively, bridges to the two Sm ions through its two different carboxylate groups.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the structure of complex 1, all H2BDC molecules are completely deprotonated and all oxygen atoms from the carboxylic groups of BDC anions take part in coordination with metal ions. The BDC anions adopt only one type of coordination mode: two bridging bidentates () to coordinate with Sm ions. In the asymmetric unit, there are three BDC anions (), each of which, respectively, bridges to the two Sm ions through its two different carboxylate groups.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The Sm(III) ions are not coplanar but form parallel helixes on a layer (). The arrangement of Sm atoms in 2D structure is shown in . For the three BDC anions of Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BDC)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, all adopt the a coordination mode to bind Sm atoms. Due to the same coordination mode, the distances between adjacent Sm ions are almost same (Sm⋯Sm=4.713, 4.739<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The adjacent Sm ions form distorted ten-membered rings and extend helix chains, which are connected by BDC anions coordination mode a, forming a 2D infinite network ([1,0,1]). The distance between two helixes is about 6.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (Sm⋯Sm). The adjacent layers are stacked at an interplane distance of ∼13.57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The view of 2D structure of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is shown in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Sm(III) ions are not coplanar but form parallel helixes on a layer (). The arrangement of Sm atoms in 2D structure is shown in . For the three BDC anions of Sm2(BDC)3(H2O)2, all adopt the a coordination mode to bind Sm atoms. Due to the same coordination mode, the distances between adjacent Sm ions are almost same (Sm⋯Sm=4.713, 4.739Å). The adjacent Sm ions form distorted ten-membered rings and extend helix chains, which are connected by BDC anions coordination mode a, forming a 2D infinite network ([1,0,1]). The distance between two helixes is about 6.45Å (Sm⋯Sm). The adjacent layers are stacked at an interplane distance of ~13.57Å. The view of 2D structure of complex 1 is shown in .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Comparing the title complexes with lanthanide 1,2-benzenedicarboxylate (1,2-BDC) complex  and lanthanide 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (1,4-BDC) complex , we can see that the benzenedicarboxylic acids are all completely deprotonated and all the oxygen atoms coordinate to the Ln ions into extended structures. But owing to the different positions of three carboxylate groups (<ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-, <ce:italic>meta</ce:italic>- and <ce:italic>para</ce:italic>- position), the coordination modes are obviously different. 1,2-BDC can adopt coordination modes in which two oxygen atoms belonging to two carboxylate groups of one 1,2-BDC bind one metal ion. For 1,3-BDC or 1,4-BDC, the two carboxylic groups are isolated by the benzene ring and are in <ce:italic>meta</ce:italic>- or <ce:italic>para</ce:italic>- position. Because of the long distance of two carboxylate groups, 1,3-BDC and 1,4-BDC cannot adopt the coordination modes as 1,2-BDC, but usually adopt the tetradentate coordination mode (mode a in ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Comparing the title complexes with lanthanide 1,2-benzenedicarboxylate (1,2-BDC) complex  and lanthanide 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (1,4-BDC) complex , we can see that the benzenedicarboxylic acids are all completely deprotonated and all the oxygen atoms coordinate to the Ln ions into extended structures. But owing to the different positions of three carboxylate groups (ortho-, meta- and para- position), the coordination modes are obviously different. 1,2-BDC can adopt coordination modes in which two oxygen atoms belonging to two carboxylate groups of one 1,2-BDC bind one metal ion. For 1,3-BDC or 1,4-BDC, the two carboxylic groups are isolated by the benzene ring and are in meta- or para- position. Because of the long distance of two carboxylate groups, 1,3-BDC and 1,4-BDC cannot adopt the coordination modes as 1,2-BDC, but usually adopt the tetradentate coordination mode (mode a in ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Luminescence spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The emission spectra and the excitation spectra of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>. The left of the figure is the excitation curve, the other is the emission curve which consist of two strong peaks attributed to <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> electronic transitions at 593 nm and <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>→<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> electronic transitions at 617.5 nm . Because of the experimental condition of RT, the resolution of the line transitions cannot be improved, thus sharper lines cannot be distinguished in the excitation spectra.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence spectroscopy

The emission spectra and the excitation spectra of 2 are presented in  . The left of the figure is the excitation curve, the other is the emission curve which consist of two strong peaks attributed to 5D0→7F1 electronic transitions at 593 nm and 5D0→7F2 electronic transitions at 617.5 nm . Because of the experimental condition of RT, the resolution of the line transitions cannot be improved, thus sharper lines cannot be distinguished in the excitation spectra.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Two lanthanide m-phthalate complexes with 2D layer structure have been obtained by hydrothermal synthesis and characterized by X-ray crystallography. The results show that the carboxylate groups of BDC ligands adopt coordination mode: bridging bidentate. The Ln(III) ions are bridged by carboxylate groups of BDC forming a layer structure which is composed by parallel helix chains, while layers are stacked to form a 2D structure. In addition, IR spectra and XRD support the results of the X-ray analysis. The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is proved to be a potential luminescent material by its luminescence spectroscopy.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two lanthanide m-phthalate complexes with 2D layer structure have been obtained by hydrothermal synthesis and characterized by X-ray crystallography. The results show that the carboxylate groups of BDC ligands adopt coordination mode: bridging bidentate. The Ln(III) ions are bridged by carboxylate groups of BDC forming a layer structure which is composed by parallel helix chains, while layers are stacked to form a 2D structure. In addition, IR spectra and XRD support the results of the X-ray analysis. The complex 2 is proved to be a potential luminescent material by its luminescence spectroscopy.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of complexes

A mixture of Ln2O3 (0.5 mmol; Sm2O3, 174 mg; Eu2O3, 176 mg), 36% HCl 0.3 ml (0.36 mmol), 1.5 mmol of 1,3-BDC acid (250 mg), 0.5 ml 3,5-lutidine and 10 ml H2O was put into a 23 ml Teflon coated stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 4 days. After cooled to room temperature naturally, a large amount of needle-liked crystals were obtained. The crystals were separated by vacuum filtration and washed with distill water and absolute alcohol.

[Sm2(BDC)3(H2O)2] n  (1). Yield: 286 mg (69%). Found: C, 34.59; H, 1.65. C24H16O14Sm2 requires: C, 34.77; H, 1.95. IR (cm-1): 3439s, 3080m, 1613vs, 1546vs, 1479s, 1453vs, 1389vs, 1188m, 1161m, 1077m, 826w, 745s, 713s, 701m, 655w, 581m, 540m, 423m.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

This article presents two lanthanide coordination polymers, [Ln2(BDC)3(H2O)2] n  (Ln=Sm, 1; Ln=Eu, 2; BDC=1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) prepared by the hydrothermal technique, in the presence of 3,5-lutidine. The two complexes are characterized by IR spectra and X-ray diffraction. The luminescent spectroscopy of complex 2 has also been investigated. Crystal data: 1, C24H16O14Sm2, Monoclinic, P21/n, a=13.362(4)Å, b=14.475(3)Å, c=13.568(2)Å, β=104.058(9)°, V=2545.7(10)Å3, Z=4, μ=4.642mm-1, D calc=2.163g/cm3, R 1=0.0237, wR 2=0.0587; 2, C24H16O14Eu2, Monoclinic, P21/n, a=13.316(4)Å, b=14.437(3)Å, c=13.540(2)Å, β=103.956(9)°, V=2526.1(10)Å3, Z=4, μ=4.994mm-1, D calc=2.188g/cm3, R 1=0.0373, wR 2=0.1184. In these structures, Ln ions connecting with BDC anions are distributed in a helix-like 2D network, which is interlinked together by carboxylic groups.

[Eu2(BDC)3(H2O)2] n  (2). Yield: 266 mg (64%). Found: C, 34.78; H, 1.94. C24H16O14Eu2 requires: C, 34.63; H, 1.94. IR (cm-1): 3453s, 3083m, 1614vs, 1548vs, 1480s, 1454vs, 1390vs, 1190m, 1163m, 1078m, 827w, 746s, 713s, 701m, 655w, 581m, 542m, 423m.

Structures of [Ln2(BDC)3(H2O)2] n  (Ln=Sm, 1; Ln=Eu, 2)

Single crystal XRD studies revealed that the structure of complex 1 is a 2D coordination polymer made up of layers. The asymmetric unit of 1 is depicted in   and selected bond distances are listed in  . There are two crystallographically independent samarium ions in the asymmetric unit. The coordination environment of Sm1 is pentagonal bipyramidal. The pentagonal plane is composed of four carboxylate oxygen atoms and a water oxygen atom, and the two apical sites are taken by another two carboxylate oxygen atoms. The coordination polyhedron around Sm2 is a capped trigonal prism that contains six carboxylate oxygen atoms and one water oxygen atom (). The Sm-O distances range from 2.298(3) to 2.546(3)Å, giving the average bond distance of 2.392(2)Å. The distance of Sm1⋯Sm2 is 4.739Å.
